posts.name: Rijoy Sarkar
posts.cooked: Our team has been using an 8 Falcon Mk4 drivetrain with an L2 ratio and have had a positive experience so far. However, considering the probable discontinuation of Falcons and the enhanced capabilities of the Kraken motor, we are exploring the possibility of switching to Kraken motors. Based on the information gathered, transitioning would require purchasing 3-4 additional Krakens and 4 pinion sets, costing approximately $700-$900 in total. Fortunately, we already have some spare Falcons, minimizing the risk of motor failures. Our primary goal is to enhance our drivetrain. We are wondering if this switch is financially worthwhile, if there are additional components we might need, and what other improvements could further boost our system.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Krakens deliver a bit more power and are a bit more efficient at high currents. However, overall, I don’t think the performance difference matters much unless your team is exceptionally skilled. I’d prioritize building a reliable robot and fine-tuning its mechanisms over drivetrain power. If you’re experiencing reliability issues with Falcons that you believe are caused by the drivetrain, that might be a stronger reason to switch compared to minor power differences.  

Kraken drives are generally reliable, and I’d recommend dedicating the remaining power from Falcons to other systems instead.  

Budgeting for torque wrenches from **CTRE** or **WCP** with Kraken drives is crucial to prevent motor damage from over-torquing terminal screws.  

The most significant improvement for your drivetrain likely comes from programming and practice. Study top-tier teams' code to simplify swerve control.  

An additional tip: Analyze past matches to assess how much time was spent moving from point A to B versus tasks like alignment or placement. This could provide insights into areas needing improvement.

link_counts.title: WildStang Robotics Program: Team 111 and 112 Build Blog - 2025

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I don’t think there will be a significant boost in performance from switching gears. I would recommend experimenting with different gear ratios and improving software and practicing driving techniques. While krakens are powerful and can be used on other systems, they likely won’t make a drastically noticeable difference, as far as I know.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: Currently, we use falcons for steer and krakens for drive. Since falcons are NLA, we plan to switch entirely to kraken. However, there isn’t a significant cost advantage beyond what we already have with falcons.

posts.name: Rijoy Sarkar
posts.cooked: We already have four krakens but are using them for mechanisms, so we plan to purchase around three more. Any additional krakens could be useful. This year, our drivetrain has been slow, and I'm unsure why—this is my first year in the FIRST Robotics Competition. Which teams have the best swerve code? We will test different ratios during the offseason and plan to rebuild our swerve modules due to some issues we've encountered.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
The teams whose code I examine most often are 254, 1678, 6328, and 2910, but it’s crucial to understand the underlying principles rather than mindlessly copying their code, as their solutions might be overly complex compared to what a less experienced team would use. I’m unsure if there’s a more accessible alternative I could recommend.

Programming aspects to consider include whether limiting the acceleration improves controllability, if a slower mode with reduced velocity and acceleration would offer better control, and adding buttons to snap the robot to specific angles (as we had for coral stations). When observing your matches, the robot seems fast enough but could benefit from smoother driving and more practiced handling.

posts.name: Rijoy Sarkar
posts.cooked: We have implemented a slow mode and adjusted the bot's positioning to snap to preset areas. However, we believe we could optimize the center of gravity to reduce the bot's jerking during movement. Additionally, we plan to allocate more resources to improve driver practice. I suggested prioritizing this because our lead programmer, who is soon graduating, emphasized the need for increased autonomous speed. While I’m unsure about the accuracy of this approach or whether I misunderstood the situation, based on the current information, I question whether the added cost of the kraken swerve feature is justified. Therefore, we will focus on enhancing software capabilities and practice instead.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Extremely important: Do not output anything but the cleaned version.  

I think it depends on how old your Falcon 500 motors are. We used a full Falcon 500 swerve throughout all of 2023 and competed in one race in the #2 position in 2024. Over time, we noticed increasing issues with the motors. Before the #4 race, we switched the drive motor to a Kraken and saw a slight performance improvement. This year, we also used a Kraken as the steering motor because our Falcon 500s are outdated, and we didn't have time to test other motors like the Neo.

posts.name: Trevor Dayal (he/him)
posts.cooked: It is also game specific. In games with full-field cycling (2023, 2024), a higher maximum speed is important (favoring lower ratios with more powerful motors), while in half-field or quarter-field games (2019, 2025), better acceleration and mechanism speed are more critical (likely favoring falcons at a higher ratio with faster mechanisms). You can perform some drivetrain calculations on recalc to aid in making decisions. There was a great thread previously discussing current limits, with 3005 performing well with vortices, and many teams using Neos.

link_counts.title: PSA: Your Motor Curves Are Wrong (A Whitepaper About Current Limits)

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: What are you using for steering encoders and a gyro? If all your electronics are from Cross The Road Electronics (CTRE), you can generate swerve drivetrain code using TunerX. This swerve code is what many top teams use.
